name: places/ChIJ0XtRcJRYwokR54eDMGaTbbM
adrFormatAddress: 955 5th Ave, New York, NY 10075, USA

originalText.text:
I developed a ganglion cyst on my wrist due to weightlifting. My primary doctor gave me two options: he could use a needle to drain it, or I could consult a hand and wrist specialist. I chose to see a specialist, and he referred me to Dr. Lenzo. The fact that they were able to schedule an appointment for the same day should have raised some concerns right away.

Upon arriving at Dr. Lenzo's office, they immediately asked for payment for an X-ray and my co-payment. I explained that I didn't need an X-ray because the cyst was visibly protruding from my skin, and my primary doctor had indicated it was an easy fix. However, they insisted that Dr. Lenzo's policy required an X-ray before he would see anyone. This was another red flag.

After the X-ray was taken, Dr. Lenzo did not discuss the results with me as most doctors typically do. Instead, he suggested using hydrocortisone to treat the cyst rather than the standard procedure of draining it with a needle. It later came to my attention, through my insurance company, that this choice was likely motivated by financial gain, as there is more money to be made from administering hydrocortisone.

Dr. Lenzo assured me that the cyst would dissipate within a week and that I should be fine. Before leaving, I requested a copy of the X-rays to add to my medical records. However, Dr. Lenzo office uses an outdated system that doesn't produce digital copies like other doctors in the city. They gave me small 5 by 5-inch pictures of the X-rays.

Later that day, I intended to scan the X-rays and upload them to my medical app at Langone. It was then that I realized Dr. Lenzo had provided me with two identical copies of the same X-ray instead of all three, further adding to my frustration. So instead of the full set of three that were taken, he gave me 2 of the same and did not check to make sure he was giving his patient the right info which was frustrating and felt like a waste of time and money.

Subsequently, I tried contacting Dr. Lenzo team to address these issues, but they either seemed uninformed about what had transpired or chose to feign ignorance. They told me the $89 I paid for the X-RAY had nothing to do with the X-RAY.  If feels like they are making it up as you go along.  The receptionist told me it would be an additional $5 per X-RAY. I asked to speak to the office Manager and I was on hold for over 20 minutes before I finally hung up.  It became evident that Dr. Lenzo may be approaching retirement age and could be prioritizing maximizing profits at the expense of his patients' well-being. Unfortunately, after three weeks, the pain and the size of the cyst have not improved.

originalText.text: I've had 9 surgeries in my life. Dr Lenzo did a very specialized procedure on my right hand. 20+ years later. This is the only surgery that I've healed 99% from. Dr. Lenzo was personable and top shelf.

text.text: I've had 9 surgeries in my life. Dr Lenzo did a very specialized procedure on my right hand. 20+ years later. This is the only surgery that I've healed 99% from. Dr. Lenzo was personable and top shelf.

originalText.text: This is a wonderful Dr. as well as a great surgeon.

text.text: This is a wonderful Dr. as well as a great surgeon.

originalText.text:
It was one of the worst experiences I've ever had with a doctor's office. I was lied to and charged and sent to a collections agency after the office manager, Yolanda agreed on a lesser amount with me. Very unprofessional. I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND TO ANYONE.

I reported them to the BBB, and they reached out to them twice. There was no response from their end. It clearly shows that they know they did something unethical so they could make their money. It is not ok to bully a person into going to an appointment especially after they tell you that you aren't interested in a $300.00 consultation. Be careful with this office.

originalText.text: Simple trigger finger surgery resulted in crippling RSI, carpel tunnel, dequervain and cubital tunnel.  He was dismissive of crippling nerve pain, refused to take responsibility, and kept me waiting all day until an entire waiting room of 25 patients emptied.  Humiliation as a medical doctors tactic is not becoming.  He then resisted completing the essential paperwork necessary to receive benefits.  Stay away, don’t go, dangerous.
